content:
Assuming what needs to be proved is a logical fallacy known as "begging the question," also called "circular reasoning." It occurs when an argument's premises assume the truth of the conclusion, making the argument circular and not actually proving anything.

Here's an example of begging the question fallacy:

"God exists because the Bible says so, and the Bible is true because it is the word of God."

In this argument, the premise (the Bible is true because it is the word of God) is simply restating the conclusion (God exists). The argument is circular, and therefore does not provide any real evidence or proof for the existence of God.

Another example of begging the question could be:

"Abortion is wrong because it is the taking of an innocent life."

In this argument, the premise assumes that the fetus is a "life" and "innocent," which are the very things being debated. This argument does not actually provide any evidence or reasoning to support the conclusion that abortion is wrong.
